Dunning\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982250_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 08:31\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T08:31:03+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 08:31\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe h2o integration work has been progressing nicely.  It is located at \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/github.com\\/tdunning\\/h2o-matrix\\\" class=\\\"external-link\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/tdunning\\/h2o-matrix\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe rationale for doing the work externally is largely the non-technical opposition from Dmitriy.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe current status is that a reasonably performance implementation of the basic java math API which is sufficient for coding up a basic k-means.  This work will be progressing to integration within the Scala DSL as well as basic implementations of other algorithms such as SSVD.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eOnce basic integration with the Scala DSL works sufficiently for the test piece algorithms, it will make sense to bring this work back into Mahout.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSo far, communications have been handled by direct email.  This is somewhat unsatisfactory in that the discussions are not publicly visible.  I expect that as soon as the work comes back into Mahout itself, this issue will resolve itself.\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"tdunning\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982250_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=tdunning\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"tdunning\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Ted Dunning\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982250_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 08:31\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T08:31:03+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 08:31\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    The h2o integration work has been progressing nicely.  It is located at  \\n\\n  https:\\/\\/github.com\\/tdunning\\/h2o-matrix  \\n\\n The rationale for doing the work externally is largely the non-technical opposition from Dmitriy. \\n\\n The current status is that a reasonably performance implementation of the basic java math API which is sufficient for coding up a basic k-means.  This work will be progressing to integration within the Scala DSL as well as basic implementations of other algorithms such as SSVD. \\n\\n Once basic integration with the Scala DSL works sufficiently for the test piece algorithms, it will make sense to bring this work back into Mahout. \\n\\n So far, communications have been handled by direct email.  This is somewhat unsatisfactory in that the discussions are not publicly visible.  I expect that as soon as the work comes back into Mahout itself, this issue will resolve itself.              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-13982481\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap verbose actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Collapse comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-links\\\"\u003e\\n                \u003ca href=\\\"\\/jira\\/browse\\/MAHOUT-1500?focusedCommentId=13982481&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13982481\\\"\\n                   title=\\\"Right click and copy link for a permanent link to this comment.\\\" class=\\\"activitymodule-link issue-comment-action\\\"\u003e\\n                    \u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-link\\\"\u003ePermalink\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n                                            \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details\\\"\u003e        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982481_verbose\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlyubimov\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Dmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982481_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 21:41\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T21:41:35+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 21:41\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe rationale for doing the work externally is largely the non-technical opposition from Dmitriy.\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eNot sure what is not technical in my previous post. Or pretty much any post attached to this jira on my behalf. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eI am glad some github code is finally officially confirmed to be tied to this very M-1500 issue for the first time.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, i very much don\'t want to get pulled into discussion on height measurements of moral grounds here. Which is why it is the last time i post on this issue, since it obviously became pretty toxic for me to touch since desire to discredit-by-spin of my position has become so palpable. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eI have measured technical merit of those arguments given to me so far, privately or publicly, while consciously pushing objectivity levers of mine into their extreme \\\"max\\\" position; and unfortunately i don\'t think i found much substance to overcome the problems i have already reported. \u003cb\u003eBut this is just a matter of opinion. And i already gave 0 vote on this. So i don\'t see why you would want to do anything different w.r.t. submitting this work for further review with people on this forum\u003c\\/b\u003e based solely on my arguments &#8211; even if i have been privy to some additional information about this development before it was announced. I am not significant from the progress of this work point of view. My arguments might be of some value though. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSo, for the last time, to recap what it was.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e(A) critique of the idea of having anything blockwise-distributed under Matrix api as it exists today\u003c\\/b\u003e.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eAs i mentioned above, the x2o-matrix code itself refers to core contracts as \\\"performance bug\\\" ( here we mean in-core abstraction of element-wise direct access, element-wise and vector-wise iterators, and in-core optimizer specific contracts). If implementation cannot satisfy core contracts of abstraction, it follows directly that the abstraction is not useful for the implementation. In other words, if the algorithms using abstraction need to pay attention to what actual implementation class actually lies underneath, then again, abstraction has failed by definition. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eConcerns like that could be allayed in some (not common) cases by declaring operations optionally supported (e.g. as in ByteBuffer$array()). However, in such situations optional contract is planned in the very first place rather than by alteration, as it would likely break existing users of the abstaction. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eOptional contracts also do not cover so numerous and so core-concern contracts as suggested by this \\\"performance bug\\\" qualifier (like i said, 95% of current Mahout code is using elementwise or vector-wise iterators whenever Matrix or Vector type is involved). So I don\'t consider declaring optional support for the family of those in-core contracts of Matrix and Vector a reconciliation path for this design problem.  \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eAnd I haven\'t heard any solid technical rebuttal to this from OOA point of view that would somehow vindicate this design in my mind.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eEnd-of-critique. Alternatives\u003c\\/b\u003e \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e(B)\u003c\\/b\u003e Alternaltively, suppose we really wanted to go this way (i.e. marry something like \\\"h2o-ized variation of DistributedRowMatrix\\\" with AbstractMatrix using common mix-ins), then ideally solid design would imply  re-working Matrix apis in order to split them further to separate into finer classes of concerns than those that exist today: algebraic ops, incore optimizer ops, and  element-wise access concerns for in-core and distributed models (i.e stuff like getQuick, setQuick and Iterable vs. mapBlock). \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eAnd then we would say that we have some mix-in (interface) that addresses all algebraic ops regardless of whether it is distributed or in-core backing.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThis sounds kind of right, doesn\'t it.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, this brings us back to the  issue of destabilizing in-core Matrix api, splitting interfaces into hair, and hence sending ripple effects of code refactoring throughout, perhaps even beyond Mahout codebase. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThis cost in my opinion is not sufficiently outweighed by benefits of having some common in-core and distributed algebraic mix-ins among distributed and in-core stuff. Instead, algebraic operator-centric approach in my experience turned out much more cleaner pragmatically from distributed optimizer point of view,  and resulted in much cleaner separation of in-core and distributed math concerns even in the end-user algorithms. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eFurther on, even purely algebraic stuff is unlikely to be totally common (e.g. slice operators for vectors and elements are not supported in distributed stuff &#8211; instead, mapBlock operator is implied there to get access to  in-core iterators of the blocks; in-place operators are generally bad for distributed plans too). This means even further split of API which at first seemed to be fairly same for both in-core and distributed stuff. That\'s my pragmatical net remainder of the Spark bindings work.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e(C)\u003c\\/b\u003e Another angle of attack on x2o integration IMO would be plugging x2o engines  into optimizer, which this work (M-1500) doesn\'t target. I rate possibility of this happening as quite tepid at the moment, because x2o programming model is not rich enough to provide things like zipping identically distributed datasets, very general shuffle model (e.g. many-to-many shuffle), advanced partition management (shuffless resplit-coalesce), and so on. I am not even sure if there\'s a clear concept of combiner type operation.  That observation leaves very bleak prospects for physical layer realization of the DRMLike scala stuff using H2O.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSo when \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=tdunning\\\" class=\\\"user-hover\\\" rel=\\\"tdunning\\\"\u003eTed Dunning\u003c\\/a\u003e speaks of DSL integration, he most probably speaks of Scala bindings, not distributed DSL bindings. So this will create further fragmentation of approaches and goes against \\\"write once, run anywhere\\\" concept there. More likely, with this approach there would be \\\"write once for H2O\\\" and \\\"write once for everything else\\\". Which is not end of the world, but it doesn\'t sound appealing and it certainly doesn\'t seem to imply coherent H20 integration &#8211; not coherent with distributed algebra bindings, anyway.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e(D)\u003c\\/b\u003e And yet a third thought i probably have not yet said in this jira: I think the best path for any sort of benefits from x20 integration would be borrowing the compression techniques for columnar in-core data frame blocks, that\'s where x2o strength is said to be above anything else.  But at this point my understanding no one has any intention to work this angle either.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eI am not supportive of A and B as explained. \u003cbr\\/\u003e\\nI am dubious about but not i am not sufficiently qualified to judge on C alternative.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\nI am supportive of alternative D.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThank you for reading till the end.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e-d\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982481_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlyubimov\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Dmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982481_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 21:41\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T21:41:35+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 21:41\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                     The rationale for doing the work externally is largely the non-technical opposition from Dmitriy.  \\n\\n Not sure what is not technical in my previous post. Or pretty much any post attached to this jira on my behalf.  \\n\\n I am glad some github code is finally officially confirmed to be tied to this very M-1500 issue for the first time. \\n\\n However, i very much don\'t want to get pulled into discussion on height measurements of moral grounds here. Which is why it is the last time i post on this issue, since it obviously became pretty toxic for me to touch since desire to discredit-by-spin of my position has become so palpable.  \\n\\n I have measured technical merit of those arguments given to me so far, privately or publicly, while consciously pushing objectivity levers of mine into their extreme \\\"max\\\" position; and unfortunately i don\'t think i found much substance to overcome the problems i have already reported.  But this is just a matter of opinion. And i already gave 0 vote on this. So i don\'t see why you would want to do anything different w.r.t. submitting this work for further review with people on this forum  based solely on my arguments &#8211; even if i have been privy to some additional information about this development before it was announced. I am not significant from the progress of this work point of view. My arguments might be of some value though.  \\n\\n So, for the last time, to recap what it was. \\n\\n  (A) critique of the idea of having anything blockwise-distributed under Matrix api as it exists today . \\n\\n As i mentioned above, the x2o-matrix code itself refers to core contracts as \\\"performance bug\\\" ( here we mean in-core abstraction of element-wise direct access, element-wise and vector-wise iterators, and in-core optimizer specific contracts). If implementation cannot satisfy core contracts of abstraction, it follows directly that the abstraction is not useful for the implementation. In other words, if the algorithms using abstraction need to pay attention to what actual implementation class actually lies underneath, then again, abstraction has failed by definition.  \\n\\n Concerns like that could be allayed in some (not common) cases by declaring operations optionally supported (e.g. as in ByteBuffer$array()). However, in such situations optional contract is planned in the very first place rather than by alteration, as it would likely break existing users of the abstaction.  \\n\\n Optional contracts also do not cover so numerous and so core-concern contracts as suggested by this \\\"performance bug\\\" qualifier (like i said, 95% of current Mahout code is using elementwise or vector-wise iterators whenever Matrix or Vector type is involved). So I don\'t consider declaring optional support for the family of those in-core contracts of Matrix and Vector a reconciliation path for this design problem.   \\n\\n And I haven\'t heard any solid technical rebuttal to this from OOA point of view that would somehow vindicate this design in my mind. \\n\\n  End-of-critique. Alternatives   \\n\\n  (B)  Alternaltively, suppose we really wanted to go this way (i.e. marry something like \\\"h2o-ized variation of DistributedRowMatrix\\\" with AbstractMatrix using common mix-ins), then ideally solid design would imply  re-working Matrix apis in order to split them further to separate into finer classes of concerns than those that exist today: algebraic ops, incore optimizer ops, and  element-wise access concerns for in-core and distributed models (i.e stuff like getQuick, setQuick and Iterable vs. mapBlock).  \\n\\n And then we would say that we have some mix-in (interface) that addresses all algebraic ops regardless of whether it is distributed or in-core backing. \\n\\n This sounds kind of right, doesn\'t it. \\n\\n However, this brings us back to the  issue of destabilizing in-core Matrix api, splitting interfaces into hair, and hence sending ripple effects of code refactoring throughout, perhaps even beyond Mahout codebase.  \\n\\n This cost in my opinion is not sufficiently outweighed by benefits of having some common in-core and distributed algebraic mix-ins among distributed and in-core stuff. Instead, algebraic operator-centric approach in my experience turned out much more cleaner pragmatically from distributed optimizer point of view,  and resulted in much cleaner separation of in-core and distributed math concerns even in the end-user algorithms.  \\n\\n Further on, even purely algebraic stuff is unlikely to be totally common (e.g. slice operators for vectors and elements are not supported in distributed stuff &#8211; instead, mapBlock operator is implied there to get access to  in-core iterators of the blocks; in-place operators are generally bad for distributed plans too). This means even further split of API which at first seemed to be fairly same for both in-core and distributed stuff. That\'s my pragmatical net remainder of the Spark bindings work. \\n\\n  (C)  Another angle of attack on x2o integration IMO would be plugging x2o engines  into optimizer, which this work (M-1500) doesn\'t target. I rate possibility of this happening as quite tepid at the moment, because x2o programming model is not rich enough to provide things like zipping identically distributed datasets, very general shuffle model (e.g. many-to-many shuffle), advanced partition management (shuffless resplit-coalesce), and so on. I am not even sure if there\'s a clear concept of combiner type operation.  That observation leaves very bleak prospects for physical layer realization of the DRMLike scala stuff using H2O. \\n\\n So when  Ted Dunning  speaks of DSL integration, he most probably speaks of Scala bindings, not distributed DSL bindings. So this will create further fragmentation of approaches and goes against \\\"write once, run anywhere\\\" concept there. More likely, with this approach there would be \\\"write once for H2O\\\" and \\\"write once for everything else\\\". Which is not end of the world, but it doesn\'t sound appealing and it certainly doesn\'t seem to imply coherent H20 integration &#8211; not coherent with distributed algebra bindings, anyway. \\n\\n  (D)  And yet a third thought i probably have not yet said in this jira: I think the best path for any sort of benefits from x20 integration would be borrowing the compression techniques for columnar in-core data frame blocks, that\'s where x2o strength is said to be above anything else.  But at this point my understanding no one has any intention to work this angle either. \\n\\n I am not supportive of A and B as explained.  \\nI am dubious about but not i am not sufficiently qualified to judge on C alternative. \\nI am supportive of alternative D. \\n\\n Thank you for reading till the end. \\n\\n -d              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-13982497\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap verbose actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Collapse comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-links\\\"\u003e\\n                \u003ca href=\\\"\\/jira\\/browse\\/MAHOUT-1500?focusedCommentId=13982497&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13982497\\\"\\n                   title=\\\"Right click and copy link for a permanent link to this comment.\\\" class=\\\"activitymodule-link issue-comment-action\\\"\u003e\\n                    \u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-link\\\"\u003ePermalink\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n                                            \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details\\\"\u003e        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"tdunning\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982497_verbose\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=tdunning\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"tdunning\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Ted Dunning\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982497_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 22:50\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T22:50:38+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 22:50\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlieu.7%40gmail.com\\\" class=\\\"user-hover\\\" rel=\\\"dlieu.7@gmail.com\\\"\u003eDmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\'s comments have several incorrect statements which lead to incorrect conclusions.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThese statements are both explicit and implicit and include in paraphrased form:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\\t\u003cli\u003eA comment about a \\\"performance bug\\\" means that h2o can\'t implement the Matrix API\u003c\\/li\u003e\\n\u003c\\/ul\u003e\\n\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThis means that use of some operations may have impacts on performance that could be surprisingly large to some programmers.  The comment is intended to warn implementors that these impacts could be large enough to essentially prevent benefit from parallel computation.  As such, their use would thwart some of the purpose of using a parallel system.  The reference to a \\\"performance bug\\\" does not imply that the operations do not work and, indeed, their availability might be handy during initial implementation of algorithms.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSection (A) makes points about validity of abstractions due to the requirements to modify existing code, but that really doesn\'t apply since that isn\'t the purpose of the current work.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\\t\u003cli\u003eIt is the intent of the h2o support of the Matrix API that all codes that use the Matrix API should run and get parallel speedup\u003c\\/li\u003e\\n\u003c\\/ul\u003e\\n\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is explicitly not a goal of the current effort.  The goal of the current effort is to use a well understood and stable Mahout API to experiment with implementation techniques for parallel algorithms that are based on h2o.  It is a premise of this effort that the operations used in these hand built implementations will have roughly similar execution patterns as will equivalent programs that use the Scala bindings or the distributed DSL bindings.  That premise is unlikely to be massively incorrect and thus the current effort is useful in terms of determining good h2o idioms for implementing matrix code.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe pattern of usage of the matrix API by other Mahout codes is completely irrelevant to this effort.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\\t\u003cli\u003eThe h2o system is not rich enough in capabilities to support things like zipping identically distributed data sets.\u003c\\/li\u003e\\n\u003c\\/ul\u003e\\n\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is simply incorrect and is based on lack of knowledge of the h2o system.  The h2o primitives are different from Spark primitives.  That means that different idioms have to be used to generate similar results, but it doesn\'t mean that h2o lacks these capabilities.  In particular, the discord between what \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlieu.7%40gmail.com\\\" class=\\\"user-hover\\\" rel=\\\"dlieu.7@gmail.com\\\"\u003eDmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e thinks that h2o can do and what it can do is large enough that the entire section (C) in his comments is essentially vacuous since it is based entirely on false premises.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe current results indicate that there considerable promise for h2o in terms of these capabilities.  More work is indicated.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\\t\u003cli\u003ethe current work would require massive revamping of the current Mahout Matrix API.\u003c\\/li\u003e\\n\u003c\\/ul\u003e\\n\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe current work is a technical exploration of convenient and efficient implementation techniques.  It has no implications whatsoever regarding the refactoring of the Mahout Matrix API.  The current work does have implications relative to any h2o shim layers that might ultimately be necessary, but that has nothing to do with the current Mahout in-core API\'s.  Section (B) is thus also moot.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eThe emotional tenor of \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlieu.7%40gmail.com\\\" class=\\\"user-hover\\\" rel=\\\"dlieu.7@gmail.com\\\"\u003eDmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\'s comments are exactly what is encouraging the h2o work to be done a bit apart.  It simply isn\'t efficient to have to answer so many off-topic points whenever any reports on work in progress are given.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\\n\\n \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"tdunning\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982497_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=tdunning\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"tdunning\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Ted Dunning\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982497_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'27\\/Apr\\/14 22:50\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-27T22:50:38+0000\'\u003e27\\/Apr\\/14 22:50\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                     Dmitriy Lyubimov \'s comments have several incorrect statements which lead to incorrect conclusions. \\n\\n These statements are both explicit and implicit and include in paraphrased form: \\n\\n \\n\\t A comment about a \\\"performance bug\\\" means that h2o can\'t implement the Matrix API \\n \\n\\n\\n This means that use of some operations may have impacts on performance that could be surprisingly large to some programmers.  The comment is intended to warn implementors that these impacts could be large enough to essentially prevent benefit from parallel computation.  As such, their use would thwart some of the purpose of using a parallel system.  The reference to a \\\"performance bug\\\" does not imply that the operations do not work and, indeed, their availability might be handy during initial implementation of algorithms. \\n\\n Section (A) makes points about validity of abstractions due to the requirements to modify existing code, but that really doesn\'t apply since that isn\'t the purpose of the current work. \\n\\n \\n\\t It is the intent of the h2o support of the Matrix API that all codes that use the Matrix API should run and get parallel speedup \\n \\n\\n\\n This is explicitly not a goal of the current effort.  The goal of the current effort is to use a well understood and stable Mahout API to experiment with implementation techniques for parallel algorithms that are based on h2o.  It is a premise of this effort that the operations used in these hand built implementations will have roughly similar execution patterns as will equivalent programs that use the Scala bindings or the distributed DSL bindings.  That premise is unlikely to be massively incorrect and thus the current effort is useful in terms of determining good h2o idioms for implementing matrix code. \\n\\n The pattern of usage of the matrix API by other Mahout codes is completely irrelevant to this effort. \\n\\n \\n\\t The h2o system is not rich enough in capabilities to support things like zipping identically distributed data sets. \\n \\n\\n\\n This is simply incorrect and is based on lack of knowledge of the h2o system.  The h2o primitives are different from Spark primitives.  That means that different idioms have to be used to generate similar results, but it doesn\'t mean that h2o lacks these capabilities.  In particular, the discord between what  Dmitriy Lyubimov  thinks that h2o can do and what it can do is large enough that the entire section (C) in his comments is essentially vacuous since it is based entirely on false premises. \\n\\n The current results indicate that there considerable promise for h2o in terms of these capabilities.  More work is indicated. \\n\\n \\n\\t the current work would require massive revamping of the current Mahout Matrix API. \\n \\n\\n\\n The current work is a technical exploration of convenient and efficient implementation techniques.  It has no implications whatsoever regarding the refactoring of the Mahout Matrix API.  The current work does have implications relative to any h2o shim layers that might ultimately be necessary, but that has nothing to do with the current Mahout in-core API\'s.  Section (B) is thus also moot. \\n\\n The emotional tenor of  Dmitriy Lyubimov \'s comments are exactly what is encouraging the h2o work to be done a bit apart.  It simply isn\'t efficient to have to answer so many off-topic points whenever any reports on work in progress are given. \\n\\n\\n\\n             \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-13982714\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n and copy link for a permanent link to this comment.\\\" class=\\\"activitymodule-link issue-comment-action\\\"\u003e\\n                    \u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small   \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982714_verbose\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlyubimov\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982714_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'28\\/Apr\\/14 02:38\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-28T02:38:02+0000\'\u003e28\\/Apr\\/14 02:38\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese statements are both explicit and implicit and include in paraphrased form:\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eA comment about a \\\"performance bug\\\" means that h2o can\'t implement the Matrix API\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe reference to a \\\"performance bug\\\" does not imply that the operations do not work and, indeed, their availability might be handy during initial implementation of algorithms.\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eParaphrasing me means admitting i did not say that. I am well aware that these APIs in question are \u003cem\u003enaively\u003c\\/em\u003e supported. When a person takes an iterator (regardless of what one iterates over) it is expected as a general rule that would be a O\u003cimg class=\\\"emoticon\\\" src=\\\"\\/jira\\/images\\/icons\\/emoticons\\/thumbs_down.png\\\" height=\\\"16\\\" width=\\\"16\\\" align=\\\"absmiddle\\\" alt=\\\"\\\" border=\\\"0\\\"\\/\u003e iteration. Using it for O(1) is not a general rule (in fact, i don\'t know example of that over entire current codebase). \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSo thus we established two things here: \u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n(1) abstraction is not useful for general rule. O\u003cimg class=\\\"emoticon\\\" src=\\\"\\/jira\\/images\\/icons\\/emoticons\\/thumbs_down.png\\\" height=\\\"16\\\" width=\\\"16\\\" align=\\\"absmiddle\\\" alt=\\\"\\\" border=\\\"0\\\"\\/\u003e \u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n(2) abstraction may be useful for non-general rule O(1). \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eSo according to general rule, this abstraction is not useful. Saying that general rule can be overturned by special case is a fallacy in retorics called \\\"special pleading\\\", i.e. arguing against general rule based on an exception.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eentire section (C) in his comments is essentially vacuous since it is based entirely on false premises\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eProposal (C) actually stated the proposal (implement optimizer plugin for h20) and also argumentation why it may be difficult. I am not sure what is moot &#8211; the proposal, or why it is unfeasible. Either way, it is based on my discussion with h20 team and their own admittance(including dev list) that programming model is not where it needs be. If they know that these goodies are provided as primitives they never stated so. I was actually very hopeful and positive about it in the beginning that there were. You are the first person on record on the topic that advertises H20 as rich programming model. If so, that\'s wonderful, i would be happy to re-examine my proposal C myself. That said, i already admitted I should not be considered an expert on the exact set of capabilities there. My point with proposal (C) was that giving physical layer translation for h20 things is viewed as  more consistent integration path, but not so much why it is unfeasible. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe emotional tenor of Dmitriy Lyubimov\'s comments are exactly what is encouraging the h2o work to be done a bit apart. It simply isn\'t efficient to have to answer so many off-topic points whenever any reports on work in progress are given.\u003c\\/p\u003e\u003c\\/blockquote\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eI think this has been the off-topic here. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eCalling my comments \\\"emotional\\\" or \\\"non-technical\\\", or \u003cem\u003eloosely\u003c\\/em\u003e paraphrasing me. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eIt is also a well known rhetorical fallacy &#8211; attacking opponent\'s character or expertise with hope he or she would go into defending it while distracting from the actual issue at hand.  Which allows to mount even further similar attacks. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eBut it wouldn\'t matter even if I  ate children for dinner, discussion of my character (or expertise) is totally irrelevant to this Jira or strength argumentation of whomever. Rhethorics would argue this actually makes your position look weaker, making people think the rest of your argumentation base is weaker than it is. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eAnyway, I just wanted to make it clear that I don\'t see it as reasonable to use my name as any sort of pretext to do (or not to do) things as opposed that they are normally done in Apache. I am also willing to make it easier since I will not return to this jira and will not vote negatively on it. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eActually quite opposite, i have always had and will encourage to bring things more forward for people to look at, not being clear on intent was what has been causing so much confusion about this all in the first place.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13982714_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=dlyubimov\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"dlyubimov\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e Dmitriy Lyubimov\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_13982714_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'28\\/Apr\\/14 02:38\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-04-28T02:38:02+0000\'\u003e28\\/Apr\\/14 02:38\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                     These statements are both explicit and implicit and include in paraphrased form:  \\n  A comment about a \\\"performance bug\\\" means that h2o can\'t implement the Matrix API  \\n  The reference to a \\\"performance bug\\\" does not imply that the operations do not work and, indeed, their availability might be handy during initial implementation of algorithms.  \\n\\n Paraphrasing me means admitting i did not say that. I am well aware that these APIs in question are  naively  supported. When a person takes an iterator (regardless of what one iterates over) it is expected as a general rule that would be a O  iteration. Using it for O(1) is not a general rule (in fact, i don\'t know example of that over entire current codebase).  \\n\\n So thus we established two things here:  \\n(1) abstraction is not useful for general rule. O   \\n(2) abstraction may be useful for non-general rule O(1).  \\n\\n So according to general rule, this abstraction is not useful. Saying that general rule can be overturned by special case is a fallacy in retorics called \\\"special pleading\\\", i.e. arguing against general rule based on an exception. \\n\\n  entire section (C) in his comments is essentially vacuous since it is based entirely on false premises  \\n\\n Proposal (C) actually stated the proposal (implement optimizer plugin for h20) and also argumentation why it may be difficult. I am not sure what is moot &#8211; the proposal, or why it is unfeasible. Either way, it is based on my discussion with h20 team and their own admittance(including dev list) that programming model is not where it needs be. If they know that these goodies are provided as primitives they never stated so. I was actually very hopeful and positive about it in the beginning that there were. You are the first person on record on the topic that advertises H20 as rich programming model. If so, that\'s wonderful, i would be happy to re-examine my proposal C myself. That said, i already admitted I should not be considered an expert on the exact set of capabilities there. My point with proposal (C) was that giving physical layer translation for h20 things is viewed as  more consistent integration path, but not so much why it is unfeasible.  \\n\\n  The emotional tenor of Dmitriy Lyubimov\'s comments are exactly what is encouraging the h2o work to be done a bit apart. It simply isn\'t efficient to have to answer so many off-topic points whenever any reports on work in progress are given.  \\n\\n I think this has been the off-topic here.  \\n\\n Calling my comments \\\"emotional\\\" or \\\"non-technical\\\", or  loosely  paraphrasing me.  \\n\\n It is also a well known rhetorical fallacy &#8211; attacking opponent\'s character or expertise with hope he or she would go into defending it while distracting from the actual issue at hand.  Which allows to mount even further similar attacks.  \\n\\n But it wouldn\'t matter even if I  ate children for dinner, discussion of my character (or expertise) is totally irrelevant to this Jira or strength argumentation of whomever. Rhethorics would argue this actually makes your position look weaker, making people think the rest of your argumentation base is weaker than it is.  \\n\\n Anyway, I just wanted to make it clear that I don\'t see it as reasonable to use my name as any sort of pretext to do (or not to do) things as opposed that they are normally done in Apache. I am also willing to make it easier since I will not return to this jira and will not vote negatively on it.  \\n\\n Actually quite opposite, i have always had and will encourage to bring things more forward for people to look at, not being clear on intent was what has been causing so much confusion about this all in the first place. \\n             \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-13984369\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap verbose actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Collapse comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-links\\\"\u003e\\n                \u003ca href=\\\"\\/jira\\/browse\\/MAHOUT-1500?focusedCommentId=13984369&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13984369\\\"\\n                   title=\\\"Right click and copy link for a permanent link to this comment.\\\" class=\\\"activitymodule-link issue-comment-action\\\"\u003e\\n                    \u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-link\\\"\u003ePermalink\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n                                            \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details\\\"\u003e        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"kanjilal\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_13984369_verbose\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=kanjilal\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg h2o\\/src\\/test\\/scala\\/org\\/apache\\/mahout\\/math\\/decompositions\\/MathSuite.scala &#8212;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    @@ -0,0 +1,212 @@\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\\/*\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * You may obtain a copy of the License at\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + *\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + *     \u003ca href=\\\"http:\\/\\/www.apache.org\\/licenses\\/LICENSE-2.0\\\" class=\\\"external-link\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttp:\\/\\/www.apache.org\\/licenses\\/LICENSE-2.0\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + *\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in express or implied.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * limitations under the License.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + *\\/\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +package org.apache.mahout.math.decompositions\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.scalatest.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{Matchers, FunSuite}\\n\u003cp\u003e    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings.test.MahoutLocalContext\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.math._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import drm._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import scalabindings._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import RLikeOps._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import RLikeDrmOps._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.common.RandomUtils\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import scala.math._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +class MathSuite extends FunSuite with Matchers with MahoutLocalContext {\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"thin distributed qr\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +\\n    +    val A = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +    val (drmQ, inCoreR) = dqrThin(A, checkRankDeficiency = false)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert optimizer still knows Q and A are identically partitioned\\n    +    drmQ.partitioningTag should equal(A.partitioningTag)\\n    +\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.partitions.size should be(A.rdd.partitions.size)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Should also be zippable\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.zip(other = A.rdd)\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreQ = drmQ.collect\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Q=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreQ)\\n    +    printf(\\\"R=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreR)\\n    +\\n    +    val (qControl, rControl) = qr(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Validate with Cholesky\\n    +    val ch = chol(inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"A\'A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"L:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", ch.getL)\\n    +\\n    +    val rControl2 = (ch.getL cloned).t\\n    +    val qControl2 = ch.solveRight(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl2)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Housholder approach seems to be a little bit more stable\\n    +    (rControl - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +    (qControl - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert identicity with in-core Cholesky-based -- this should be tighter.\\n    +    (rControl2 - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +    (qControl2 - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert orhtogonality:\\n    +    \\/\\/ (a) Q[,j] dot Q[,j] == 1.0 for all j\\n    +    \\/\\/ (b) Q[,i] dot Q[,j] == 0.0 for all i != j\\n    +    for (col &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      ((inCoreQ(::, col) dot inCoreQ(::, col)) - 1.0).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +    for (col1 &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol - 1; col2 &lt;- col1 + 1 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      (inCoreQ(::, col1) dot inCoreQ(::, col2)).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"dssvd - the naive-est - q=0\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 0)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=1\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 1)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=2\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 2)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  def dssvdNaive(q: Int) \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, s) = dssvd(drmA, k = 4, q = q)\\n    +    val (inCoreU, inCoreV) = (drmU.collect, drmV.collect)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"U:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreU)\\n    +    printf(\\\"V:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreV)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Sigma:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", s)\\n    +\\n    +    (inCoreA - (inCoreU %*%: diagv(s)) %*% inCoreV.t).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"dspca\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    val (u, _) = qr(new SparseRowMatrix(m, spectrumLen) :=\\n    +        ((r, c, v) =&gt; if (rnd.nextDouble() &lt; 0.2) 0 else rnd.nextDouble() + 5.0))\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ PCA Rotation matrix -- should also be orthonormal.\\n    +    val (tr, _) = qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(spectrumLen, spectrumLen, rnd.nextInt) - 10.0)\\n    +\\n    +    val input = (u %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*% tr.t\\n    +    val drmInput = drmParallelize(m = input, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    \\/\\/ Since we assert just validity of the s-pca, not stochastic error, we bump p parameter to\\n    +    \\/\\/ ensure to zero stochastic error and assert only functional correctness of the method\'s pca-\\n    +    \\/\\/ specific additions.\\n    +    val k = 10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    var (drmPCA, _, s) = dspca(A = drmInput, k = 10, p = spectrumLen, q = 1)\\n    +    \\/\\/ Un-normalized pca data:\\n    +    drmPCA = drmPCA %*% diagv(s)\\n    +\\n    +    val pca = drmPCA.checkpoint(CacheHint.NONE).collect\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Of course, once we calculated the pca, the spectrum is going to be different since our originally\\n    +    \\/\\/ generated input was not centered. So here, we\'d just brute-solve pca to verify\\n    +    val xi = input.colMeans()\\n    +    for (r &lt;- 0 until input.nrow) input(r, ::) -= xi\\n    +    var (pcaControl, _, sControl) = svd(m = input)\\n    +    pcaControl = (pcaControl %*%: diagv(sControl))(::, 0 until k)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"pca:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +    printf(\\\"pcaControl:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +\\n    +    (pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm - pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm).abs should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"als\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    val n = 500\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create singluar values with decay\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create A as an ideal input\\n    +    val inCoreA = (qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(m, spectrumLen, 1234))._1 %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*%\\n    +        qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(n, spectrumLen, 2345))._1.t\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Decompose using ALS\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, rmse) = als(drmInput = drmA, k = 20).toTuple\\n    +    val inCoreU = drmU.collect\\n    +    val inCoreV = drmV.collect\\n    +\\n    +    val predict = inCoreU %*% inCoreV.t\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"Control block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"ALS factorized approximation block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", predict(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +\\n    +    val err = (inCoreA - predict).norm\\n    +    printf (\\\"norm of residuals %f\\\\n\\\",err)\\n    +    printf (\\\"train iteration rmses: %s\\\\n\\\", rmse)\\n    +\\n    +    err should be &lt; 1e-2\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    &#8212; End diff &#8211;\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    I think if all these tests are passing, this would be an incredibly cool step forward in this issue..\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14036018_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14036018_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'18\\/Jun\\/14 17:47\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-06-18T17:47:08+0000\'\u003e18\\/Jun\\/14 17:47\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user dlyubimov commented on a diff in the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#discussion_r13929215  \\n\\n     &#8212; Diff: h2o\\/src\\/test\\/scala\\/org\\/apache\\/mahout\\/math\\/decompositions\\/MathSuite.scala &#8212; \\n    @@ -0,0 +1,212 @@ \\n    +\\/* \\n    + * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more \\n    + * contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file distributed with \\n    + * this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership. \\n    + * The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0 \\n    + * (the \\\"License\\\"); you may not use this file except in compliance with \\n    + * the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at \\n    + * \\n    + *      http:\\/\\/www.apache.org\\/licenses\\/LICENSE-2.0  \\n    + * \\n    + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software \\n    + * distributed under the License is distributed on an \\\"AS IS\\\" BASIS, \\n    + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. \\n    + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and \\n    + * limitations under the License. \\n    + *\\/ \\n    + \\n    +package org.apache.mahout.math.decompositions \\n    + \\n    +import org.scalatest. \\n{Matchers, FunSuite}\\n     +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings.test.MahoutLocalContext \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.math._ \\n    +import drm._ \\n    +import scalabindings._ \\n    +import RLikeOps._ \\n    +import RLikeDrmOps._ \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings._ \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.common.RandomUtils \\n    +import scala.math._ \\n    + \\n    +class MathSuite extends FunSuite with Matchers with MahoutLocalContext { \\n    + \\n    +  test(\\\"thin distributed qr\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +\\n    +    val A = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +    val (drmQ, inCoreR) = dqrThin(A, checkRankDeficiency = false)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert optimizer still knows Q and A are identically partitioned\\n    +    drmQ.partitioningTag should equal(A.partitioningTag)\\n    +\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.partitions.size should be(A.rdd.partitions.size)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Should also be zippable\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.zip(other = A.rdd)\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreQ = drmQ.collect\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Q=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreQ)\\n    +    printf(\\\"R=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreR)\\n    +\\n    +    val (qControl, rControl) = qr(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Validate with Cholesky\\n    +    val ch = chol(inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"A\'A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"L:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", ch.getL)\\n    +\\n    +    val rControl2 = (ch.getL cloned).t\\n    +    val qControl2 = ch.solveRight(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl2)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Housholder approach seems to be a little bit more stable\\n    +    (rControl - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +    (qControl - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert identicity with in-core Cholesky-based -- this should be tighter.\\n    +    (rControl2 - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +    (qControl2 - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert orhtogonality:\\n    +    \\/\\/ (a) Q[,j] dot Q[,j] == 1.0 for all j\\n    +    \\/\\/ (b) Q[,i] dot Q[,j] == 0.0 for all i != j\\n    +    for (col &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      ((inCoreQ(::, col) dot inCoreQ(::, col)) - 1.0).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +    for (col1 &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol - 1; col2 &lt;- col1 + 1 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      (inCoreQ(::, col1) dot inCoreQ(::, col2)).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"dssvd - the naive-est - q=0\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 0)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=1\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 1)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=2\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 2)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    + \\n    +  def dssvdNaive(q: Int)  \\n{\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, s) = dssvd(drmA, k = 4, q = q)\\n    +    val (inCoreU, inCoreV) = (drmU.collect, drmV.collect)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"U:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreU)\\n    +    printf(\\\"V:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreV)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Sigma:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", s)\\n    +\\n    +    (inCoreA - (inCoreU %*%: diagv(s)) %*% inCoreV.t).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"dspca\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    val (u, _) = qr(new SparseRowMatrix(m, spectrumLen) :=\\n    +        ((r, c, v) =&gt; if (rnd.nextDouble() &lt; 0.2) 0 else rnd.nextDouble() + 5.0))\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ PCA Rotation matrix -- should also be orthonormal.\\n    +    val (tr, _) = qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(spectrumLen, spectrumLen, rnd.nextInt) - 10.0)\\n    +\\n    +    val input = (u %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*% tr.t\\n    +    val drmInput = drmParallelize(m = input, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    \\/\\/ Since we assert just validity of the s-pca, not stochastic error, we bump p parameter to\\n    +    \\/\\/ ensure to zero stochastic error and assert only functional correctness of the method\'s pca-\\n    +    \\/\\/ specific additions.\\n    +    val k = 10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    var (drmPCA, _, s) = dspca(A = drmInput, k = 10, p = spectrumLen, q = 1)\\n    +    \\/\\/ Un-normalized pca data:\\n    +    drmPCA = drmPCA %*% diagv(s)\\n    +\\n    +    val pca = drmPCA.checkpoint(CacheHint.NONE).collect\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Of course, once we calculated the pca, the spectrum is going to be different since our originally\\n    +    \\/\\/ generated input was not centered. So here, we\'d just brute-solve pca to verify\\n    +    val xi = input.colMeans()\\n    +    for (r &lt;- 0 until input.nrow) input(r, ::) -= xi\\n    +    var (pcaControl, _, sControl) = svd(m = input)\\n    +    pcaControl = (pcaControl %*%: diagv(sControl))(::, 0 until k)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"pca:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +    printf(\\\"pcaControl:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +\\n    +    (pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm - pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm).abs should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"als\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    val n = 500\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create singluar values with decay\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create A as an ideal input\\n    +    val inCoreA = (qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(m, spectrumLen, 1234))._1 %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*%\\n    +        qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(n, spectrumLen, 2345))._1.t\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Decompose using ALS\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, rmse) = als(drmInput = drmA, k = 20).toTuple\\n    +    val inCoreU = drmU.collect\\n    +    val inCoreV = drmV.collect\\n    +\\n    +    val predict = inCoreU %*% inCoreV.t\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"Control block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"ALS factorized approximation block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", predict(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +\\n    +    val err = (inCoreA - predict).norm\\n    +    printf (\\\"norm of residuals %f\\\\n\\\",err)\\n    +    printf (\\\"train iteration rmses: %s\\\\n\\\", rmse)\\n    +\\n    +    err should be &lt; 1e-2\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     &#8212; End diff &#8211; \\n\\n     I think if all these tests are passing, this would be an incredibly cool step forward in this issue..              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n express or implied.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + * limitations under the License.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    + *\\/\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +package org.apache.mahout.math.decompositions\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.scalatest.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{Matchers, FunSuite}\\n\u003cp\u003e    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings.test.MahoutLocalContext\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.math._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import drm._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import scalabindings._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import RLikeOps._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import RLikeDrmOps._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import org.apache.mahout.common.RandomUtils\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +import scala.math._\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +class MathSuite extends FunSuite with Matchers with MahoutLocalContext {\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"thin distributed qr\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +\\n    +    val A = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +    val (drmQ, inCoreR) = dqrThin(A, checkRankDeficiency = false)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert optimizer still knows Q and A are identically partitioned\\n    +    drmQ.partitioningTag should equal(A.partitioningTag)\\n    +\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.partitions.size should be(A.rdd.partitions.size)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Should also be zippable\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.zip(other = A.rdd)\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreQ = drmQ.collect\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Q=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreQ)\\n    +    printf(\\\"R=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreR)\\n    +\\n    +    val (qControl, rControl) = qr(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Validate with Cholesky\\n    +    val ch = chol(inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"A\'A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"L:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", ch.getL)\\n    +\\n    +    val rControl2 = (ch.getL cloned).t\\n    +    val qControl2 = ch.solveRight(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl2)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Housholder approach seems to be a little bit more stable\\n    +    (rControl - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +    (qControl - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert identicity with in-core Cholesky-based -- this should be tighter.\\n    +    (rControl2 - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +    (qControl2 - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert orhtogonality:\\n    +    \\/\\/ (a) Q[,j] dot Q[,j] == 1.0 for all j\\n    +    \\/\\/ (b) Q[,i] dot Q[,j] == 0.0 for all i != j\\n    +    for (col &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      ((inCoreQ(::, col) dot inCoreQ(::, col)) - 1.0).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +    for (col1 &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol - 1; col2 &lt;- col1 + 1 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      (inCoreQ(::, col1) dot inCoreQ(::, col2)).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"dssvd - the naive-est - q=0\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 0)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=1\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 1)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=2\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 2)\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  def dssvdNaive(q: Int) \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, s) = dssvd(drmA, k = 4, q = q)\\n    +    val (inCoreU, inCoreV) = (drmU.collect, drmV.collect)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"U:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreU)\\n    +    printf(\\\"V:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreV)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Sigma:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", s)\\n    +\\n    +    (inCoreA - (inCoreU %*%: diagv(s)) %*% inCoreV.t).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"dspca\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    val (u, _) = qr(new SparseRowMatrix(m, spectrumLen) :=\\n    +        ((r, c, v) =&gt; if (rnd.nextDouble() &lt; 0.2) 0 else rnd.nextDouble() + 5.0))\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ PCA Rotation matrix -- should also be orthonormal.\\n    +    val (tr, _) = qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(spectrumLen, spectrumLen, rnd.nextInt) - 10.0)\\n    +\\n    +    val input = (u %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*% tr.t\\n    +    val drmInput = drmParallelize(m = input, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    \\/\\/ Since we assert just validity of the s-pca, not stochastic error, we bump p parameter to\\n    +    \\/\\/ ensure to zero stochastic error and assert only functional correctness of the method\'s pca-\\n    +    \\/\\/ specific additions.\\n    +    val k = 10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    var (drmPCA, _, s) = dspca(A = drmInput, k = 10, p = spectrumLen, q = 1)\\n    +    \\/\\/ Un-normalized pca data:\\n    +    drmPCA = drmPCA %*% diagv(s)\\n    +\\n    +    val pca = drmPCA.checkpoint(CacheHint.NONE).collect\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Of course, once we calculated the pca, the spectrum is going to be different since our originally\\n    +    \\/\\/ generated input was not centered. So here, we\'d just brute-solve pca to verify\\n    +    val xi = input.colMeans()\\n    +    for (r &lt;- 0 until input.nrow) input(r, ::) -= xi\\n    +    var (pcaControl, _, sControl) = svd(m = input)\\n    +    pcaControl = (pcaControl %*%: diagv(sControl))(::, 0 until k)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"pca:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +    printf(\\\"pcaControl:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +\\n    +    (pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm - pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm).abs should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  test(\\\"als\\\") \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    val n = 500\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create singluar values with decay\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create A as an ideal input\\n    +    val inCoreA = (qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(m, spectrumLen, 1234))._1 %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*%\\n    +        qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(n, spectrumLen, 2345))._1.t\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Decompose using ALS\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, rmse) = als(drmInput = drmA, k = 20).toTuple\\n    +    val inCoreU = drmU.collect\\n    +    val inCoreV = drmV.collect\\n    +\\n    +    val predict = inCoreU %*% inCoreV.t\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"Control block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"ALS factorized approximation block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", predict(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +\\n    +    val err = (inCoreA - predict).norm\\n    +    printf (\\\"norm of residuals %f\\\\n\\\",err)\\n    +    printf (\\\"train iteration rmses: %s\\\\n\\\", rmse)\\n    +\\n    +    err should be &lt; 1e-2\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    &#8212; End diff &#8211;\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    With the latest git-push, all these tests are passing\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14039440_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14039440_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'20\\/Jun\\/14 22:08\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-06-20T22:08:34+0000\'\u003e20\\/Jun\\/14 22:08\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user avati commented on a diff in the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#discussion_r14043524  \\n\\n     &#8212; Diff: h2o\\/src\\/test\\/scala\\/org\\/apache\\/mahout\\/math\\/decompositions\\/MathSuite.scala &#8212; \\n    @@ -0,0 +1,212 @@ \\n    +\\/* \\n    + * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more \\n    + * contributor license agreements.
