+import org.scalatest. \\n{Matchers, FunSuite}\\n     +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings.test.MahoutLocalContext \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.math._ \\n    +import drm._ \\n    +import scalabindings._ \\n    +import RLikeOps._ \\n    +import RLikeDrmOps._ \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.h2obindings._ \\n    +import org.apache.mahout.common.RandomUtils \\n    +import scala.math._ \\n    + \\n    +class MathSuite extends FunSuite with Matchers with MahoutLocalContext { \\n    + \\n    +  test(\\\"thin distributed qr\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +\\n    +    val A = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +    val (drmQ, inCoreR) = dqrThin(A, checkRankDeficiency = false)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert optimizer still knows Q and A are identically partitioned\\n    +    drmQ.partitioningTag should equal(A.partitioningTag)\\n    +\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.partitions.size should be(A.rdd.partitions.size)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Should also be zippable\\n    +\\/\\/    drmQ.rdd.zip(other = A.rdd)\\n    +\\n    +    val inCoreQ = drmQ.collect\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Q=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreQ)\\n    +    printf(\\\"R=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreR)\\n    +\\n    +    val (qControl, rControl) = qr(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Validate with Cholesky\\n    +    val ch = chol(inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"A\'A=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA.t %*% inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"L:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", ch.getL)\\n    +\\n    +    val rControl2 = (ch.getL cloned).t\\n    +    val qControl2 = ch.solveRight(inCoreA)\\n    +    printf(\\\"qControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", qControl2)\\n    +    printf(\\\"rControl2=\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", rControl2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Housholder approach seems to be a little bit more stable\\n    +    (rControl - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +    (qControl - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert identicity with in-core Cholesky-based -- this should be tighter.\\n    +    (rControl2 - inCoreR).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +    (qControl2 - inCoreQ).norm should be &lt; 1E-10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Assert orhtogonality:\\n    +    \\/\\/ (a) Q[,j] dot Q[,j] == 1.0 for all j\\n    +    \\/\\/ (b) Q[,i] dot Q[,j] == 0.0 for all i != j\\n    +    for (col &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      ((inCoreQ(::, col) dot inCoreQ(::, col)) - 1.0).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +    for (col1 &lt;- 0 until inCoreQ.ncol - 1; col2 &lt;- col1 + 1 until inCoreQ.ncol)\\n    +      (inCoreQ(::, col1) dot inCoreQ(::, col2)).abs should be &lt; 1e-10\\n    +\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"dssvd - the naive-est - q=0\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 0)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=1\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 1)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"ddsvd - naive - q=2\\\")  \\n{\\n    +    dssvdNaive(q = 2)\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    + \\n    +  def dssvdNaive(q: Int)  \\n{\\n    +    val inCoreA = dense(\\n    +      (1, 2, 3, 4),\\n    +      (2, 3, 4, 5),\\n    +      (3, -4, 5, 6),\\n    +      (4, 5, 6, 7),\\n    +      (8, 6, 7, 8)\\n    +    )\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, s) = dssvd(drmA, k = 4, q = q)\\n    +    val (inCoreU, inCoreV) = (drmU.collect, drmV.collect)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"U:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreU)\\n    +    printf(\\\"V:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreV)\\n    +    printf(\\\"Sigma:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", s)\\n    +\\n    +    (inCoreA - (inCoreU %*%: diagv(s)) %*% inCoreV.t).norm should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"dspca\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    val (u, _) = qr(new SparseRowMatrix(m, spectrumLen) :=\\n    +        ((r, c, v) =&gt; if (rnd.nextDouble() &lt; 0.2) 0 else rnd.nextDouble() + 5.0))\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ PCA Rotation matrix -- should also be orthonormal.\\n    +    val (tr, _) = qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(spectrumLen, spectrumLen, rnd.nextInt) - 10.0)\\n    +\\n    +    val input = (u %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*% tr.t\\n    +    val drmInput = drmParallelize(m = input, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    \\/\\/ Since we assert just validity of the s-pca, not stochastic error, we bump p parameter to\\n    +    \\/\\/ ensure to zero stochastic error and assert only functional correctness of the method\'s pca-\\n    +    \\/\\/ specific additions.\\n    +    val k = 10\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Calculate just first 10 principal factors and reduce dimensionality.\\n    +    var (drmPCA, _, s) = dspca(A = drmInput, k = 10, p = spectrumLen, q = 1)\\n    +    \\/\\/ Un-normalized pca data:\\n    +    drmPCA = drmPCA %*% diagv(s)\\n    +\\n    +    val pca = drmPCA.checkpoint(CacheHint.NONE).collect\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Of course, once we calculated the pca, the spectrum is going to be different since our originally\\n    +    \\/\\/ generated input was not centered. So here, we\'d just brute-solve pca to verify\\n    +    val xi = input.colMeans()\\n    +    for (r &lt;- 0 until input.nrow) input(r, ::) -= xi\\n    +    var (pcaControl, _, sControl) = svd(m = input)\\n    +    pcaControl = (pcaControl %*%: diagv(sControl))(::, 0 until k)\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"pca:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +    printf(\\\"pcaControl:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10))\\n    +\\n    +    (pca(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm - pcaControl(0 until 10, 0 until 10).norm).abs should be &lt; 1E-5\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     + \\n    +  test(\\\"als\\\")  \\n{\\n    +\\n    +    val rnd = RandomUtils.getRandom\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Number of points\\n    +    val m = 500\\n    +    val n = 500\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Length of actual spectrum\\n    +    val spectrumLen = 40\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create singluar values with decay\\n    +    val spectrum = dvec((0 until spectrumLen).map(x =&gt; 300.0 * exp(-x) max 1e-3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"spectrum:%s\\\\n\\\", spectrum)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Create A as an ideal input\\n    +    val inCoreA = (qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(m, spectrumLen, 1234))._1 %*%: diagv(spectrum)) %*%\\n    +        qr(Matrices.symmetricUniformView(n, spectrumLen, 2345))._1.t\\n    +    val drmA = drmParallelize(inCoreA, numPartitions = 2)\\n    +\\n    +    \\/\\/ Decompose using ALS\\n    +    val (drmU, drmV, rmse) = als(drmInput = drmA, k = 20).toTuple\\n    +    val inCoreU = drmU.collect\\n    +    val inCoreV = drmV.collect\\n    +\\n    +    val predict = inCoreU %*% inCoreV.t\\n    +\\n    +    printf(\\\"Control block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", inCoreA(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +    printf(\\\"ALS factorized approximation block:\\\\n%s\\\\n\\\", predict(0 until 3, 0 until 3))\\n    +\\n    +    val err = (inCoreA - predict).norm\\n    +    printf (\\\"norm of residuals %f\\\\n\\\",err)\\n    +    printf (\\\"train iteration rmses: %s\\\\n\\\", rmse)\\n    +\\n    +    err should be &lt; 1e-2\\n    +\\n    +  }\\n     &#8212; End diff &#8211; \\n\\n     With the latest git-push, all these tests are passing              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-14039447\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap verbose actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-links\\\"\u003e\\n                \u003ca href=\\\"\\/jira\\/browse\\/MAHOUT-1500?focusedCommentId=14039447&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14039447\\\"\\n                   title=\\\"Right click \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14058934_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'11\\/Jul\\/14 16:08\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-11T16:08:23+0000\'\u003e11\\/Jul\\/14 16:08\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eGithub user pferrel commented on the pull request:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48749896\\\" class=\\\"external-link\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48749896\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Are the scalatests implemented in the Spark module that covers math-scala code implemented here somewhere? I\'d vote against merge untils those are in all in place and passing.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    The cf stuff has a rather major bug the I\'m working on so I wouldn\'t move this into math-scala just yet, although it would make an interesting speed comparison once completed. The cf changes will require DSL additions that will be under separate review. Don\'t have a pr number yet.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Also I may have missed it but there should be clear instructions for how to build this and run it.  This is like a heart transplant. Before you release the patient make sure all systems are working correctly, the DSL is not the whole body. There should at least be some end-to-end pipelines in examples that anyone can run from a local installation.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Beyond these details I have a bigger issue with merging this. Now every time the DSL is changed it may break things in h20 specific code. It already does in cf for instance but I\'ve signed up to fix those fro spark. No committer has signed up to fix code in both Spark and H2O. IMO this is untenable. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    To solve this the entire data prep pipeline must be virtualized to run on either engine so the tests for things like CF and ItemSimilarity (and the multitude of others to come) pass and are engine independent. As it stands any DSL change that breaks the build will have to rely on a contributor\'s fix. Even if one of you guys was made a committer we will have this problem where a needed change breaks one or the other engine specific code. Unless 99% of the entire pipeline is engine neutral the build will be unmaintainable.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Crudely speaking this means doing away with all references to a SparkContext and any use of it. So it\'s not just a matter of reproducing the spark module but reducing the need for one. Making it so small that breakages in one or the other engines code will be infrequent. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    I raised this red flag long ago but in the heat of other issues it seemed minor, but I don\'t think it can be ignored anymore.\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14058934_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14058934_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'11\\/Jul\\/14 16:08\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-11T16:08:23+0000\'\u003e11\\/Jul\\/14 16:08\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user pferrel commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48749896  \\n\\n     Are the scalatests implemented in the Spark module that covers math-scala code implemented here somewhere? I\'d vote against merge untils those are in all in place and passing. \\n\\n     The cf stuff has a rather major bug the I\'m working on so I wouldn\'t move this into math-scala just yet, although it would make an interesting speed comparison once completed. The cf changes will require DSL additions that will be under separate review. Don\'t have a pr number yet. \\n\\n     Also I may have missed it but there should be clear instructions for how to build this and run it.  This is like a heart transplant. Before you release the patient make sure all systems are working correctly, the DSL is not the whole body. There should at least be some end-to-end pipelines in examples that anyone can run from a local installation. \\n\\n     Beyond these details I have a bigger issue with merging this. Now every time the DSL is changed it may break things in h20 specific code. It already does in cf for instance but I\'ve signed up to fix those fro spark. No committer has signed up to fix code in both Spark and H2O. IMO this is untenable.  \\n\\n     To solve this the entire data prep pipeline must be virtualized to run on either engine so the tests for things like CF and ItemSimilarity (and the multitude of others to come) pass and are engine independent. As it stands any DSL change that breaks the build will have to rely on a contributor\'s fix. Even if one of you guys was made a committer we will have this problem where a needed change breaks one or the other engine specific code. Unless 99% of the entire pipeline is engine neutral the build will be unmaintainable. \\n\\n     Crudely speaking this means doing away with all references to a SparkContext and any use of it. So it\'s not just a matter of reproducing the spark module but reducing the need for one. Making it so small that breakages in one or the other engines code will be infrequent.  \\n\\n     I raised this red flag long ago but in the heat of other issues it seemed minor, but I don\'t think it can be ignored anymore.              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv This is like a heart transplant. Before you release\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; the patient make sure all systems are working correctly, the DSL is not the\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; whole body. There should at least be some end-to-end pipelines in examples\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; that anyone can run from a local installation.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    As mentioned in the email, there is a somewhat simple \\\"how to build and\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    test\\\" for both local and distributed mode in h2o\\/README.md. Larger\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    end-to-end pipelines and examples are TBD.\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14058966_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14058966_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'11\\/Jul\\/14 16:35\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-11T16:35:39+0000\'\u003e11\\/Jul\\/14 16:35\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user avati commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48753061  \\n\\n     &gt; \\n    &gt; Are the scalatests implemented in the Spark module that covers math-scala \\n    &gt; code implemented here somewhere? rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48761123\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Exactly, thanks. I see you\'ve done the same for CF also great.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    But this illustrates the problem. I need to change 50% of the tests in CF cooccurrence because they were not catching a bug. Now the tests live in two places h2o and spark. And unless I change the tests in both places the build will break. The files look virtually identical except for the imports, which is good. If that\'s true, I wonder if we could we use a Scala macro to keep the code all in one file? We might be able to take the same code and produce two artifacts that are both run at build time. That would reduce the load on devs for this kind of thing. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    However currently almost all IO code is spark specific. You must have re-implemented drm.writeDrm for h2o.  Until this is *\u003cb\u003enot\u003c\\/b\u003e* a re-implementation but is engine neutral we are going to have a growing problem. I am the only person currently working in spark specific land and only Dmitriy and Sebastian are writing for V2. When other committers get past the Scala barrier and start committing similar stuff they will immediately face this. \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    BTW I am very interested in seeing how h2o ItemSimilarityDriver compares to an h2o version. IMO this is the kind of motivation we have to see. If you implemented the driver or the reader\\/writers we could compare speed on h2o and spark. we have a large enough dataset to make it interesting.\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14059083_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14059083_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'11\\/Jul\\/14 17:46\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-11T17:46:34+0000\'\u003e11\\/Jul\\/14 17:46\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user pferrel commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48761123  \\n\\n     Exactly, thanks. I see you\'ve done the same for CF also great. \\n\\n     But this illustrates the problem. I need to change 50% of the tests in CF cooccurrence because they were not catching a bug. Now the tests live in two places h2o and spark. And unless I change the tests in both places the build will break. The files look virtually identical except for the imports, which is good. If that\'s true, I wonder if we could we use a Scala macro to keep the code all in one file? We might be able to take the same code and produce two artifacts that are both run at build time. That would reduce the load on devs for this kind of thing.  \\n\\n     However currently almost all IO code is spark specific. You must have re-implemented drm.writeDrm for h2o.  Until this is * not * a re-implementation but is engine neutral we are going to have a growing problem. I am the only person currently working in spark specific land and only Dmitriy and Sebastian are writing for V2. When other committers get past the Scala barrier and start committing similar stuff they will immediately face this.  \\n\\n     BTW I am very interested in seeing how h2o ItemSimilarityDriver compares to an h2o version. IMO this is the kind of motivation we have to see. If you implemented the driver or the reader\\/writers we could compare speed on h2o and spark. we have a large enough dataset to make it interesting.              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n If I make the change to drm I can fix spark breakage but not h2o. This bit of code is extremely stable and super simple for spark so may be a bad example but new code will not be so stable just the opposite. For each new IO operation (SparkContext dependent)  or engine tuning (SparkConf dependent) we will grow the problem. The core will become untouchable or breakage will happen in places one engineer will not be able to fix.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    This is a real issue, I need to change code in math-scala today, already have but it isn\'t pushed. For each new IO operation (SparkContext dependent)  or engine tuning (SparkConf dependent) we will grow the problem. The core will become untouchable or breakage will happen in places one engineer will not be able to fix. \\n\\n     This is a real issue, I need to change code in math-scala today, already have but it isn\'t pushed. Maybe I can do that but when they diverge further than this example I won\'t be able to. \\n\\n     You guys need to address these issues as if you were supporting two engines for all Mahout code or rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48771908\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    On Fri, Jul 11, 2014 at 11:46 AM, Pat Ferrel &lt;notifications@github.com&gt;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    wrote:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    &gt; So you don\'t see how changing the drm API or storage format will now break\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; code in two places written for two different engines?\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Changing DRM API? Yes, of course - that is the nature of the beast of\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    supporting multiple implementations behind a single abstraction. Change in\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    abstraction API will need corresponding change in all backends. That\'s the\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    reason why APIs must be designed carefully so that future changes to them\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    are estimated to be most minimum. I don\'t see how this by itself qualifies\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    as an objection.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Storage format? Neither spark nor h2o is defining any storage formats. The\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    current APIs read and write to sequence files whose formats are very well\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    defined and standardized. As far the they both read and write that common\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    format from engine neutral locations, I don\'t see any problems at all.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    If I make the change to drm I can fix spark breakage but not h2o. This bit\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; of code is extremely stable and super simple for spark so may be a bad\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; example but new code will not be so stable just the opposite. For each new\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; IO operation (SparkContext dependent) or engine tuning (SparkConf\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; dependent) we will grow the problem. The core will become untouchable or\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; breakage will happen in places one engineer will not be able to fix.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Can you please provide a more concrete example for both \\\"make change do\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    drm\\\" and \\\"new IO operation (SparkContext dependent)\\\"? It is hard for me to\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    visualize the problems you are foreseeing without more specifics.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    This is a real issue, I need to change code in math-scala today, already\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; have but it isn\'t pushed. Who knows what that will break in h2o\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; implementations? I will be changing cooccurrence tests, so have to make\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; them in two places. Maybe I can do that but when they diverge further than\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; this example I won\'t be able to.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Well, as long as you are fixing a bug in cf logic, that should be engine\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    independent. However if you are adding a new DRM API or modifying an\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    existing DRM API - that will need corresponding changes in all the engines.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    There\'s no getting around that. That\'s something we all have to live with,\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    no matter what project it is.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    &gt; You guys need to address these issues as if you were supporting two\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; engines for all Mahout code or you will never see what Mahout committers\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt; problems will be.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    &gt;\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    As I said before, please provide a concrete example of what the issues are.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    I don\'t know \u003cb\u003ewhat\u003c\\/b\u003e to fix yet.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Thanks\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14059226_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14059226_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'11\\/Jul\\/14 19:20\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-11T19:20:59+0000\'\u003e11\\/Jul\\/14 19:20\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user avati commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-48771908  \\n\\n     On Fri, Jul 11, 2014 at 11:46 AM, Pat Ferrel &lt;notifications@github.com&gt; \\n    wrote: \\n\\n     &gt; So you don\'t see how changing the drm API or storage format will now break \\n    &gt; code in two places written for two different engines? \\n    &gt; \\n    Changing DRM API? Yes, of course - that is the nature of the beast of \\n    supporting multiple implementations behind a single abstraction. Change in \\n    abstraction API will need corresponding change in all backends. That\'s the \\n    reason why APIs must be designed carefully so that future changes to them \\n    are estimated to be most minimum. I don\'t see how this by itself qualifies \\n    as an objection. \\n\\n     Storage format? Neither spark nor h2o is defining any storage formats. The \\n    current APIs read and write to sequence files whose formats are very well \\n    defined and standardized. As far the they both read and write that common \\n    format from engine neutral locations, I don\'t see any problems at all. \\n\\n     If I make the change to drm I can fix spark breakage but not h2o. This bit \\n    &gt; of code is extremely stable and super simple for spark so may be a bad \\n    &gt; example but new code will not be so stable just the opposite. For each new \\n    &gt; IO operation (SparkContext dependent) or engine tuning (SparkConf \\n    &gt; dependent) we will grow the problem. The core will become untouchable or \\n    &gt; breakage will happen in places one engineer will not be able to fix. \\n    &gt; \\n    Can you please provide a more concrete example for both \\\"make change do \\n    drm\\\" and \\\"new IO operation (SparkContext dependent)\\\"? It is hard for me to \\n    visualize the problems you are foreseeing without more specifics. \\n\\n     This is a real issue, I need to change code in math-scala today, already \\n    &gt; have but it isn\'t pushed. Who knows what that will break in h2o \\n    &gt; implementations? I will be changing cooccurrence tests, so have to make \\n    &gt; them in two places. Maybe I can do that but when they diverge further than \\n    &gt; this example I won\'t be able to. \\n    &gt; \\n    Well, as long as you are fixing a bug in cf logic, that should be engine \\n    independent. However if you are adding a new DRM API or modifying an \\n    existing DRM API - that will need corresponding changes in all the engines. \\n    There\'s no getting around that. That\'s something we all have to live with, \\n    no matter what project it is. \\n\\n\\n     &gt; You guys need to address these issues as if you were supporting two \\n    &gt; engines for all Mahout code or you will never see what Mahout committers \\n    &gt; problems will be. \\n    &gt; \\n\\n     As I said before, please provide a concrete example of what the issues are. \\n    I don\'t know  what  to fix yet. \\n\\n     Thanks              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14071882_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'23\\/Jul\\/14 15:57\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-23T15:57:30+0000\'\u003e23\\/Jul\\/14 15:57\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eGithub user cliffclick commented on the pull request:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49894450\\\" class=\\\"external-link\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49894450\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    This is a very basic port, focused on correctness &amp; completeness, with no effort for performance.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Expectation Setting: There\'s easy 2x to 10x speedups in most of the operator inner loops.  The HDFS sequence-file reader\\/writers are single-threaded-single-node; H2O\'s internal CSV reader will be easily 100x faster.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Performance work should be in later commits.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Minor comments:\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Lots of places, esp reduce() calls, could\\/should call ArrayUtils.add(this,that) instead of a loop over the arrays being added.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    H2OHelper.empty_frame looks a ton like it should call \\\"Vec.makeZero()\\\" in a loop instead of hand rolling Vecs of zeros; there\'s a version which will take a hand-rolled layout.  This call probably should move into Frame class directly.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    The technique for row-labeling seems... awkward at best.  Or at least I\'m reading that to be the purpose of using Tuple2.  I think this design needs more exploring - e.g. insert a row-column in front of the \\\"normal\\\" Frame columns, and teach the follow-on code to skip 1st column.  Note that many datasets have non-numeric cols (e.g. name, address) that cannot participate in math ops, and so most H2O algos already carry forward a notion of a set of columns being worked on.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Cliff\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14071882_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14071882_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'23\\/Jul\\/14 15:57\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-23T15:57:30+0000\'\u003e23\\/Jul\\/14 15:57\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user cliffclick commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49894450  \\n\\n     This is a very basic port, focused on correctness &amp; completeness, with no effort for performance. \\n    Expectation Setting: There\'s easy 2x to 10x speedups in most of the operator inner loops.  The HDFS sequence-file reader\\/writers are single-threaded-single-node; H2O\'s internal CSV reader will be easily 100x faster. \\n    Performance work should be in later commits. \\n\\n     Minor comments: \\n    Lots of places, esp reduce() calls, could\\/should call ArrayUtils.add(this,that) instead of a loop over the arrays being added. \\n\\n     H2OHelper.empty_frame looks a ton like it should call \\\"Vec.makeZero()\\\" in a loop instead of hand rolling Vecs of zeros; there\'s a version which will take a hand-rolled layout.  This call probably should move into Frame class directly. \\n\\n     The technique for row-labeling seems... awkward at best.  Or at least I\'m reading that to be the purpose of using Tuple2.  I think this design needs more exploring - e.g. insert a row-column in front of the \\\"normal\\\" Frame columns, and teach the follow-on code to skip 1st column.  Note that many datasets have non-numeric cols (e.g. name, address) that cannot participate in math ops, and so most H2O algos already carry forward a notion of a set of columns being worked on. \\n\\n     Cliff \\n             \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-14071920\\\" \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eGithub user avati commented on the pull request:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca I\'ll work on ArrayUtils and Vec.makeZero() usage.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Regarding row labeling, I wanted to keep the operator inner-loop free of if() and else to skip first row optionally (i.e keep the inner loop focussed on just the math.) However, now that I think, it should be possible to filter out the label vec optionally even before entering MRTask, and have both the matrix and row labels within the same Frame.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    I\'ll work on these comments and re-post. I\'ll work on ArrayUtils and Vec.makeZero() usage. \\n\\n     Regarding row labeling, I wanted to keep the operator inner-loop free of if() and else to skip first row optionally (i.e keep the inner loop focussed on just the math.) However, now that I think, it should be possible to filter out the label vec optionally even before entering MRTask, and have both the matrix and row labels within the same Frame. \\n\\n     I\'ll work on these comments and re-post. \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14072492_verbose subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'23\\/Jul\\/14 22:47\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-23T22:47:32+0000\'\u003e23\\/Jul\\/14 22:47\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e  \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-body flooded\\\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eGithub user avati commented on the pull request:\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\\\"https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49946698\\\" class=\\\"external-link\\\" rel=\\\"nofollow\\\"\u003ehttps:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49946698\u003c\\/a\u003e\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    @cliffclick I have updated with review comments. Note that even though I did away with Tuple2, I am using a new H2ODrm in place. Having the optional row in the same Frame made things very confusing for a reviewer to instantly identify if a given Frame was with row labels or without. H2ODrm has potential future uses (extra members) as well.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    I have also made the drmfromHdfs() api fall back to H2O parser (csv etc) if a given file is not a sequence file format. So this opens up the possibility to tweak the job pipeline to use csv files instead of seqfiles and gain in performance and compression.\u003c\\/p\u003e \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap concise actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Expand comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-collapsed\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShow\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-details flooded\\\"\u003e\\n                        \\n    \\n    \\n    \\n                \\n\\n    \u003ca class=\\\"user-hover user-avatar\\\" rel=\\\"githubbot\\\" id=\\\"commentauthor_14072492_concise\\\" href=\\\"\\/jira\\/secure\\/ViewProfile.jspa?name=githubbot\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar aui-avatar-xsmall\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"aui-avatar-inner\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https:\\/\\/issues.apache.org\\/jira\\/secure\\/useravatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=10452\\\" alt=\\\"githubbot\\\" \\/\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e ASF GitHub Bot\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n added a comment  - \u003cspan class=\'commentdate_14072492_concise subText\'\u003e\u003cspan class=\'date user-tz\' title=\'23\\/Jul\\/14 22:47\'\u003e\u003ctime class=\'livestamp\' datetime=\'2014-07-23T22:47:32+0000\'\u003e23\\/Jul\\/14 22:47\u003c\\/time\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e                    Github user avati commented on the pull request: \\n\\n      https:\\/\\/github.com\\/apache\\/mahout\\/pull\\/21#issuecomment-49946698  \\n\\n     @cliffclick I have updated with review comments. Note that even though I did away with Tuple2, I am using a new H2ODrm in place. Having the optional row in the same Frame made things very confusing for a reviewer to instantly identify if a given Frame was with row labels or without. H2ODrm has potential future uses (extra members) as well. \\n\\n     I have also made the drmfromHdfs() api fall back to H2O parser (csv etc) if a given file is not a sequence file format. So this opens up the possibility to tweak the job pipeline to use csv files instead of seqfiles and gain in performance and compression.              \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n    \u003c\\/div\u003e\\n\u003c\\/div\u003e\\n                             \\n\\n\\n\u003cdiv id=\\\"comment-14072526\\\" class=\\\"issue-data-block activity-comment twixi-block  expanded\\\"\u003e\\n    \u003cdiv class=\\\"twixi-wrap verbose actionContainer\\\"\u003e\\n        \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-head\\\"\u003e\\n            \u003ca href=\\\"#\\\" title=\\\"Collapse comment\\\" class=\\\"twixi\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"icon-default aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-expanded\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHide\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/span\u003e\u003c\\/a\u003e\\n            \u003cdiv class=\\\"action-links\\\"\u003e\\n                \u003ca In that sense, help is needed. Surely, benefits of cross peer code review should really require no specific justification. This is code review on github (which is our reviewboard replacement) &#8211; you just need to look at the code, poke it if possible, leave suggestions, or just say \\\"ship it\\\". I know, reviewboard was pain to use, but github PRs are so easy, so there\'s practically no pretext left not to do it as much as possible.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003eWhich begs the question. All these people who apparently said \\\"ship it\\\" on github, excluding 0xdata review,  produced exactly 0 code notes. This is code review on github (which is our reviewboard replacement) &#8211; you just need to look at the code, poke it if possible, leave suggestions, or just say \\\"ship it\\\". I know, reviewboard was pain to use, but github PRs are so easy, so there\'s practically no pretext left not to do it as much as possible. \\n\\n Which begs the question. My minimum\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    hygiene thing is line width, indentations, naming convention and operator\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    spacing (out of which, IDE can take care of everything). With Sean\'s\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    departure, out standards on style are nowhere where they used to be.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    in scala, style is still evolving, but I pushed a few things in particular.\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    Baseline is to follow the Spark code style (and btw they are very strict\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    about it; e..g they insist that i write comments which are starting with\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    capital letter and aligned at 100th character on the right, which IDE\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    cannot do automatically). +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +public class H2OBCast&lt;T&gt; implements BCast&lt;T&gt;, Serializable {\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  transient T obj;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  byte buf[];\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  boolean is_matrix;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  public H2OBCast(T o) {\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +    obj = o;\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +    if (o instanceof Matrix) \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +      buf = serialize(new MatrixWritable((Matrix)o));\\n    +      is_matrix = true;\\n    +    }\\n\u003cp\u003e else if (o instanceof Vector) \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +      buf = serialize(new VectorWritable((Vector)o));\\n    +    }\\n\u003cp\u003e else \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +      throw new IllegalArgumentException(\\\"Only Matrix or Vector supported for now\\\");\\n    +    }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +  }\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  public T value() \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n{\\n    +    if (obj == null)\\n    +      obj = deserialize(buf);\\n    +    return obj;\\n    +  }\\n\u003cp\u003e    +\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +  private byte[] serialize(Writable w) {\u003cbr\\/\u003e\\n    +    ByteArrayOutputStream bos = Is there a way to get a 1.6 artifact in here?   Please someone let me know if I\'m being overly cautious here.  \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Long story short- looks good to me:  +1 from me on merging if we can get that artifact issue solved (or if it is really a non-issue). \u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Looking back at the email archive over the past few months, I do share many of the concerns that have been brought up,  Especially regarding documentation of spark\\/h20 supported algorithms, and think that we need to get that up quickly.\u003c\\/p\u003e\\n\\n\u003cp\u003e    Someone with a better working knowledge of h2o and scala\\/DSL may want to assign this and review it further and merge. Is there a way to get a 1.6 artifact in here?
